bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Albert E. Truby, September 2, 1942

div1.p: Kellogg provides Hench's address, at Camp Carson, and writes that he hopes Truby's manuscript will be released soon.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Albert E. Truby, September 2, 1942
div1.p:
Pardon me for not answering your letter of
August 10 at an earlier date, but I have been away from my
office most of the time during the past three weeks. I am
glad that you met Lieut. Col. Hench in Washington. His
present address is
Camp Carson
Station Hospital
Colorado Springs
Colorado

I hope that your manuscript is released by
the surgeon general's office at an early date. I was in
Washington last week and spent some time with Gen. C. C.
Hillman and Lieut. Col. Leon L. Gardiner. The latter, as I
understand it, is the censor for the Surgeon General's office.

I understand that my secretary has sent you a
number of copies of the Yellow Fever blotter and the little
booklet on “Pioneers of American Medicine”.

If the American Medical Association keep
their word about the 1943 Convention being held in San
Francisco, I will see you then.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, George A. Kellogg Gen. Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco
California
GAK:L
cc to Dr. Hench
